frameDefinitions: An Event begins at a certain Time and Place.
Words in this frame have to do with a Cognizer believing that some Phenomenon will take place in the future.
These words refer to Parts merging to form a Whole.
A Fuel, some flammable object or substance, ends up on fire.
An Entity (generally food) is exposed to a Heat_source whose Temperature may also be specified.
A New filler occupies a Role or serves a Function after the Old filler ceases to occupy the position.
frameExamples: The two droplets <t>merge</t>, and then travel down the windowpane even faster.
Bacon was <t>frying</t> in the pan, and a great heap of eggs already lay steaming on a plate.
listRoleDefinitions: Name of the <fen>Event</fen> which occurs.
When the <fen>Event</fen> occurs.
Where the <fen>Event</fen> takes place.

This is the person who believes some Phenomenon will take place in the future. It is normally expressed as an External Argument: <fex name='Cognizer'>Pat</fex> <t>expects</t> that the Yankees will win the World Series.

This is what the Cognizer believes will happen in the future. It can be expressed as a Finite Clause Complement, an NP Object, or a VP Complement with or without an NP Object (see General Grammatical Observations):
An entity that serves as the focus of a predicted <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> makes the prediction.
The location where the <fen>Cognizer</fen> foresees the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The entities that merge to form a single <fen>Whole</fen>.
The single, undifferentiated entity that is the result of the amalgamation.
The prominent entity that combines with <fen>Part_2</fen> to form a <fen>Whole</fen>.
The less focussed-upon entity that the <fen>Part_1</fen> merges with.
The time at which the <fen>Parts</fen> become amalgamated into a <fen>Whole</fen>
The location at which the amalgamation occurs.

The total material currently involved in combustion, including both the parts of the <fen>Fuel</fen> currently undergoing chemical alteration and the partially ionized gas that results from this process.
The entity that is begins to undergo rapid chemical alteration leading to damage or destruction.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Fire</fen> begins to burn.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Fire</fen> begins to burn.
The <fen>Entity</fen> (often a food item)  that absorbs heat.
The <fen>Container</fen> that holds the <fen>Entity</fen> that absorbs the heat.
This role identifies the object that directly supplies heat to the <fen>Entity</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the heat absorption takes place.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the heat application occurs.
The new filler of the <fen>Role</fen> that was previously occupied by the <fen>Old</fen> filler.
The category that the <fen>New</fen> and <fen>Old</fen> entities fit into as a result of the <fen>Function</fen> they serve.
The (generally desirable) state of affairs that the <fen>New</fen> and <fen>Old</fen> entities are involved in bringing about.
The entity that occupied the <fen>Role</fen> or served the <fen>Function</fen> before the <fen>New</fen> filler.
The time at which the <fen>New</fen> takes up the <fen>Role</fen> previously occupied by the <fen>Old</fen>.
listRoleExamples: Pat expects <fex>that the Yankees will win the World Series</fex>.
Predictions <fex>about stock prices</fex> are notoriously undependable.
She predicted the outcry <fex>several months ago</fex>.
<fex>Even at the far side of the house</fex> I could predict what was going on the kitchen.
They had all just merged <fex>into one big file</fex>.
<fex>The single smaller soul</fex> merges with the Ur-soul.
The single smaller soul merges <fex>with the Ur-soul</fex>.
<fex>Bacon</fex> frying in the pan and scenting the air
Five fat sausages were frying <fex>in the pan</fex>
Food was placed to sizzle <fex>on the barbecue </fex>.
<fex>Five minutes ago</fex>the eggs weren't boiling yet.
<fex>In the kitchen</fex> the meat sizzled in the oven and a big pan of potatoes stood on the hob
The traditional thatched roof has often been replaced <fex>by corrugated galvanized iron</fex>.
What gas replaced Hydrogen <fex>as a safer medium for use in balloons</fex> on account it does not burn?
Oil and gas replaced coal <fex>in heating homes, in industry, and in transportation</fex>.
The electron was discovered and <fex>electricity</fex> replaced gas lamps.
When electricity replaced oil <fex>in the early 1930's</fex>, the steady beam was replaced by a flashing light.
